{{See also|Minimalism|List of minimalist artists}} [[File:DonaldֹJudd IMJ.JPG|thumb|300px|[[Donald Judd]], ''Untitled,'' 1991, [[Israel Museum]] Art Garden, [[Jerusalem]].]] [[File:DFHFrankStella.jpg|thumb|[[Frank Stella]], ''[[Die Fahne Hoch! (Frank Stella)|Die Fahne Hoch!]],'' 1959, [[Whitney Museum of American Art]]]] '''Minimalism''' describes movements in various forms of art and design, especially [[Visual arts|visual art]] and [[Minimalist music|music]], where the work is set out to expose the essence, essentials or identity of a subject through eliminating all non-essential forms, features or concepts. As a specific movement in the arts it is identified with developments in post–World War II Western Art, most strongly with American visual arts in the 1960s and early 1970s. Prominent artists associated with this movement include [[Ad Reinhardt]], [[Tony Smith (sculptor)|Tony Smith]], [[Donald Judd]], [[John McCracken (artist)|John McCracken]], [[Agnes Martin]], [[Dan Flavin]], [[Robert Morris (artist)|Robert Morris]], [[Larry Bell (artist)|Larry Bell]], [[Anne Truitt]], [[Yves Klein]] and [[Frank Stella]]. Artists themselves have sometimes reacted against the label due to the negative implication of the work being simplistic.Dempsey, Amy. Styles, Schools and Movements, Thames & Hudson, 2002.] "The artists themselves did not like the label because of the negative implication that their work was simplistic and devoid of 'art content'." Minimalism is often interpreted as a reaction against [[Abstract expressionism]] and a bridge to [[Postminimalism|Postminimal]] art practices. ==Minimal art, minimalism in visual art== [[File:Tonysmith freeride sculpture.jpg|thumb|270px|[[Tony Smith (sculptor)|Tony Smith]], ''Free Ride'', 1962, 6'8 x 6'8 x 6'8, [[Museum of Modern Art]] (New York City)]] Minimalism in visual art, generally referred to as "minimal art", ''literalist art'' Fried, M. "Art and Objecthood", ''Artforum'', 1967 and ''ABC Art''Rose, Barbara. "ABC Art", ''Art in America'' 53, no. 5 (October–November 1965): 57–69. emerged in New York in the early 1960s.{{cite book|author1=Cindy Hinant|editor1-last=Meyer-Stoll|editor1-first=Christiane|title=Gary Kuehn: Between Sex and Geometry|date=2014|publisher=Snoeck Verlagsgessellschaft|location=Cologne|isbn=3864421098|page=33}} Initially minimal art appeared in New York in the 60s as new and older artists moved toward [[geometric abstraction]]; exploring via painting in the cases of [[Frank Stella]], [[Kenneth Noland]], [[Al Held]], [[Ellsworth Kelly]], [[Robert Ryman]] and others; and sculpture in the works of various artists including [[David Smith (artist)|David Smith]], [[Anthony Caro]], [[Tony Smith (sculptor)|Tony Smith]], [[Sol LeWitt]], [[Carl Andre]], [[Dan Flavin]], [[Donald Judd]] and others. Judd's sculpture was showcased in 1964 at the [[Green Gallery]] in Manhattan as were Flavin's first fluorescent light works, while other leading Manhattan galleries like the [[Leo Castelli|Leo Castelli Gallery]] and the [[Pace Gallery]] also began to showcase artists focused on geometric abstraction. In addition there were two seminal and influential museum exhibitions: ''[[Primary Structures]]: Younger American and British Sculpture''' shown from April 27 - June 12, 1966 at the [[Jewish Museum (New York)|Jewish Museum]] in [[New York City|New York]], organized by the museum's Curator of Painting and Sculpture, Kynaston McShine ''Time'' magazine, June 3, 1966, "Engineer's Esthetic", pg. 64''Newsweek'' magazine, May 16, 1966, "The New Druids", pg. 104 and ''Systemic Painting,'' at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] curated by [[Lawrence Alloway]] also in 1966 that showcased [[Geometric abstraction]] in the American art world via [[Shaped canvas]], [[Color Field]], and [[Hard-edge painting]].[http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/exhibitions/publications/from-the-archives/items/view/72 ''Systemic Painting'', Guggenheim Museum][http://www.enotes.com/oxford-art-encyclopedia/systemic-art Systemic art, Oxford-Art encyclopedia][https://books.google.com/books?id=lhMS8Ii73ZkC&pg=PA37&lpg=PA37&dq=Systemic+Painting,&source=bl&ots=NdebCUxYBJ&sig=JLIUKPxFw3KycjSoDwPKLFqRz3c&hl=en&sa=X&ei=0alTT7m1LcTz0gHhw7y8DQ&ved=0CHsQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=Systemic%20Painting%2C&f=false Lawrence Alloway, ''Systemic Painting'', Google books online] In the wake of those exhibitions and a few others the [[art movement]] called ''minimal art'' emerged. ==History== [[Jean Metzinger]], following the ''[[Succès de scandale]]'' created from the [[Cubist]] showing at the 1911 [[Salon des Indépendants]], in an interview with Cyril Berger published in ''Paris-Journal'' 29 May 1911, stated:
We cubists have only done our duty by creating a new rhythm for the benefit of humanity. Others will come after us who will do the same. What will they find? That is the tremendous secret of the future. Who knows if someday, a great painter, looking with scorn on the often brutal game of supposed colorists and taking the seven colors back to the primordial white unity that encompasses them all, will not exhibit completely white canvases, with nothing, absolutely nothing on them. (Jean Metzinger, 29 May 1911)Jean Metzinger, "Chez Metzi'', interview by Cyril Berger, published in the ''Paris-Journal'', 29 May 1911, p. 3Mark Antliff and Patricia Leighten: ''A Cubism Reader, Documents and Criticism, 1906-1914'', University of Chicago Press, 2008, Document 17, Cyril Berger, ''Chez Metzi'', Paris-Journal, 29 May 1911, pp. 108-112
[[File:Kazimir Malevich, 1915, Black Suprematic Square, oil on linen canvas, 79.5 x 79.5 cm, Tretyakov Gallery, Moscow.jpg|thumb|[[Kazimir Malevich]], ''Black Square'', 1915, oil on canvas, [[Tretyakov Gallery]], [[Moscow]][http://www.tretyakovgallery.ru/en/collection/_show/image/_id/378 Malevich, Kazimir Severinovich, ''Black Suprematic Square'', 1915, oil on canvas, 79.5 х 79.5 cm, Tretyakov Gallery, Moscow] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20140206000538/http://www.tretyakovgallery.ru/en/collection/_show/image/_id/378 |date=2014-02-06 }}]] Metzinger's (then) audacious prediction that artists would take [[abstract art|abstraction]] to its logical conclusion by vacating representational subject matter entirely and returning to what Metzinger calls the "primordial white unity", a "completely white canvas" would be realized two years later. The writer of a satirical manifesto, possibly [[Francis Picabia]], in a publication entitled ''Evolution de l'art: Vers l'amorphisme'', in ''Les Hommes du Jour'' (3 May 1913), may have had Metzinger's vision in mind when the author justified amorphism's blank canvases by claiming 'light is enough for us'. With perspective, writes art historian Jeffery S. Weiss, "''Vers Amorphisme'' may be gibberish, but it was also enough of a foundational language to anticipate the extreme reductivist implications of non-objectivity".[https://books.google.com/books?id=jj82ZE_ctIoC&pg=PA86 Jeffrey S. Weiss, ''The Popular Culture of Modern Art: Picasso, Duchamp, and Avant-gardism''], Yale University Press, 1994, {{ISBN|9780300058956}} Monochrome painting was initiated at the first [[Incoherents|Incoherent arts]]' exhibition in 1882 in Paris, with a black painting by poet [[Paul Bilhaud]] entitled "Combat de Nègres dans un tunnel" (''Negroes fight in a tunnel''). In the subsequent exhibitions of the Incoherent arts (also in the 1880s) the writer [[Alphonse Allais]] proposed seven other monochrome paintings, such as "Première communion de jeunes filles chlorotiques par un temps de neige" (''First communion of anaemic young girls in the snow'', white), or "Récolte de la tomate par des cardinaux apoplectiques au bord de la Mer Rouge" (''Tomato harvesting by apoplectic cardinals on the shore of the Red Sea'', red). However, this kind of activity bears more similarity to 20th century [[Dada]], or [[Neo-Dada]], and particularly the works of the [[Fluxus]] group of the 1960s, than to 20th century monochrome painting since Malevich. [[File:IKB 191.jpg|thumb|[[Yves Klein]], IKB 191, 1962, [[Monochrome painting]]. Klein was a pioneer in the development of Minimal art.]] In a broad and general sense, one finds European roots of minimalism in the [[geometric abstraction]]s of painters associated with the [[Bauhaus]], in the works of [[Kazimir Malevich]], [[Piet Mondrian]] and other artists associated with the [[De Stijl]] movement, and the [[Constructivism (art)|Russian Constructivist]] movement, and in the work of the Romanian sculptor [[Constantin Brâncuși]].[http://artcritical.com/2004/10/01/albert-york-and-giorgio-morandi/ Maureen Mullarkey, Art Critical, ''Giorgio Morandi''][https://books.google.com/books?id=hr-5GcN0F6kC&pg=PA12&lpg=PA12&dq=Constantin+Br%C3%A2ncu%C5%9Fi.+and+minimal+art&source=bl&ots=8fdrAkynIx&sig=_wMpgr2P-ywVUMWpAziTWIuQnjI&hl=en&ei=mRHeTr_IF6jg0QHZ55XHBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q&f=false Daniel Marzona, Uta Grosenick; ''Minimal art'', p.12] Minimal art is also inspired in part by the paintings of [[Barnett Newman]], [[Ad Reinhardt]], [[Josef Albers]], and the works of artists as diverse as [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Marcel Duchamp]], [[Giorgio Morandi]], and others. Minimalism was also a reaction against the painterly subjectivity of [[Abstract expressionism|Abstract Expressionism]] that had been dominant in the [[New York School (art)|New York School]] during the 1940s and 1950s.[https://books.google.com/books?id=lhMS8Ii73ZkC&pg=PA161&lpg=PA161&dq=abstract+expressionism+and+minimal+art&source=bl&ots=NddevTB5zD&sig=nyIwlEqV3XyQaTkeVPgZNqfOGUY&hl=en&ei=rBfeTtKeI8Pd0QG20am2Bw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CF0Q6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=abstract%20expressionism%20and%20minimal%20art&f=false Gregory Battcock, ''Minimal Art: a critical anthology'', pp 161-172] The wide range of possibilities (including impossibility) of interpretation of monochrome paintings is arguably why the monochrome is so engaging to so many artists, critics, and writers. Although the monochrome has never become dominant and few artists have committed themselves exclusively to it, it has never gone away. It reappears as though a spectre haunting [[high modernism]], or as a symbol of it, appearing during times of [[aesthetic]] and sociopolitical upheavals.''The Primary Colors for the Second Time: A Paradigm Repetition of the Neo-Avant-Garde,'' [[Benjamin H. D. Buchloh]], October, Vol. 37, (Summer, 1986), pp. 41-52 (article consists of 12 pages), Published by: [[The MIT Press]] ==Monochrome revival== In France between 1947 and 1948,{{cite web|title=Yves Klein (1928-1962)|url=http://www.yveskleinarchives.org/documents/bio_us.html|work=documents/biography|publisher=Yves Klein Archives & McDourduff|accessdate=12 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130530082903/http://www.yveskleinarchives.org/documents/bio_us.html|archivedate=30 May 2013|df=}} [[Yves Klein]] conceived his ''Monotone Symphony'' (1949, formally ''The Monotone-Silence Symphony'') that consisted of a single 20-minute sustained chord followed by a 20-minute silenceGilbert Perlein & Bruno Corà (eds) & al., ''Yves Klein: Long Live the Immaterial!'' ("An anthological retrospective", catalog of an exhibition held in 2000), New York: Delano Greenidge, 2000, {{ISBN|978-0-929445-08-3}}, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=baJPAAAAMAAJ&q=%22This+symphony%2C+40+minutes+in+length+(in+fact+20+minutes+followed+by+20+minutes+of+silence)%22&pgis=1#search_anchor 226]: "This symphony, 40 minutes in length (in fact 20 minutes followed by 20 minutes of silence) is constituted of a single 'sound' stretched out, deprived of its attack and end which creates a sensation of vertigo, whirling the sensibility outside time."See also at YvesKleinArchives.org [http://www.yveskleinarchives.org/works/works14_us.html a 1998 sound excerpt of ''The Monotone Symphony''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208181614/http://www.yveskleinarchives.org/works/works14_us.html |date=2008-12-08 }} (Flash plugin required), [http://www.yveskleinarchives.org/works/works14_texte_en.html its short description] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081028020545/http://www.yveskleinarchives.org/works/works14_texte_en.html |date=2008-10-28 }}, and Klein's [http://www.yveskleinarchives.org/documents/chelsea_content_us.html "Chelsea Hotel Manifesto"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613062110/http://yveskleinarchives.org/documents/chelsea_content_us.html |date=2010-06-13 }} (including a summary of the 2-part ''Symphony''). – a precedent to both [[La Monte Young]]'s [[drone music]] and John Cage's ''[[4′33″]]''. Although Klein had painted [[Monochrome painting|monochromes]] as early as 1949, and held the first private exhibition of this work in 1950, his first public showing was the publication of the [[Artist's book]] ''[[Yves: Peintures]]'' in November 1954.Hannah Weitemeier, ''Yves Klein, 1928–1962: International Klein Blue'', Original-Ausgabe (Cologne: Taschen, 1994), 15. {{ISBN|3-8228-8950-4}}.{{cite book|title=Modern Paint Uncovered|chapter=Restoring the Immaterial: Study and Treatment of Yves Klein's ''Blue Monochrome (IKB42)''}} Artist and critic [[Thomas Lawson (artist)|Thomas Lawson]] noted in his 1981 essay "Last Exit: Painting" [[Artforum]], October: 40-47, minimalism did not reject [[Clement Greenberg]]'s claims about modernist painting's [http://www.sharecom.ca/greenberg/modernism.html Clement Greenberg, ''Modernist Painting,'' 1960] reduction to surface and materials so much as take his claims literally. According to Lawson minimalism was the result, even though the term "minimalism" was not generally embraced by the artists associated with it, and many practitioners of art designated minimalist by critics did not identify it as a movement as such. Also taking exception to this claim was Clement Greenberg himself; in his 1978 postscript to his essay ''Modernist Painting'' he disavowed this incorrect interpretation of what he said; Greenberg wrote:
There have been some further constructions of what I wrote that go over into preposterousness: That I regard flatness and the inclosing of flatness not just as the limiting conditions of pictorial art, but as criteria of aesthetic quality in pictorial art; that the further a work advances the self-definition of an art, the better that work is bound to be. The philosopher or art historian who can envision me—or anyone at all—arriving at aesthetic judgments in this way reads shockingly more into himself or herself than into my article.''
[[File:UntitledGoldBox1964.jpg|thumb|left|[[Larry Bell (artist)|Larry Bell]], ''Untitled'' (1964), bismuth, chromium, gold, and rhodium on gold-plated brass; [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]]]] In contrast to the previous decade's more subjective [[Abstract expressionism|Abstract Expressionists]], with the exceptions of [[Barnett Newman]] and [[Ad Reinhardt]]; minimalists were also influenced by composers [[John Cage]] and [[La Monte Young|LaMonte Young]], poet [[William Carlos Williams]], and the landscape architect [[Frederick Law Olmsted]]. They very explicitly stated that their art was not about self-expression, unlike the previous decade's more subjective philosophy about art making theirs was 'objective'. In general, Minimalism's features included [[Geometry|geometric]], often [[Cube|cubic]] forms purged of much [[metaphor]], equality of parts, [[wikt:repetition|repetition]], neutral surfaces, and industrial materials. [[Robert Morris (artist)|Robert Morris]], an influential theorist and artist, wrote a three part essay, "Notes on Sculpture 1-3", originally published across three issues of ''[[Artforum]]'' in 1966. In these essays, Morris attempted to define a conceptual framework and formal elements for himself and one that would embrace the practices of his contemporaries. These essays paid great attention to the idea of the [[wikt:Gestalt|gestalt]] - "parts... bound together in such a way that they create a maximum resistance to perceptual separation." Morris later described an art represented by a "marked lateral spread and no regularized units or symmetrical intervals..." in "Notes on Sculpture 4: Beyond Objects", originally published in ''[[Artforum]]'', 1969, continuing to say that "indeterminacy of arrangement of parts is a literal aspect of the physical existence of the thing." The general shift in theory of which this essay is an expression suggests the transitions into what would later be referred to as ''[[postminimalism]]''. One of the first artists specifically associated with minimalism was the painter, [[Frank Stella]], whose early "pinstripe" paintings were included in the 1959 show, ''[[Dorothy Miller#1959: Sixteen Americans|16 Americans]],'' organized by [[Dorothy Miller]] at the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York. The width of the stripes in Frank Stellas's pinstripe paintings were determined by the dimensions of the lumber used for stretchers, visible as the depth of the painting when viewed from the side, used to construct the supportive chassis upon which the canvas was stretched. The decisions about structures on the front surface of the canvas were therefore not entirely subjective, but pre-conditioned by a "given" feature of the physical construction of the support. In the show catalog, [[Carl Andre]] noted, "Art excludes the unnecessary. Frank Stella has found it necessary to paint [[wikt:stripe|stripe]]s. There is nothing else in his painting." These reductive works were in sharp contrast to the energy-filled and apparently highly subjective and emotionally charged paintings of [[Willem de Kooning]] or [[Franz Kline]] and, in terms of precedent among the previous generation of abstract expressionists, leaned more toward the less gestural, often somber, [[color field]] paintings of [[Barnett Newman]] and [[Mark Rothko]]. Although Stella received immediate attention from the MoMA show, artists including [[Kenneth Noland]], [[Gene Davis (painter)|Gene Davis]], [[Robert Motherwell]] and [[Robert Ryman]] had also begun to explore stripes, [[Monochrome|monochromatic]] and [[Hard-edge painting|Hard-edge]] formats from the late 50s through the 1960s.[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/384056/minimalism Britannica.com] Because of a tendency in minimal art to exclude the pictorial, illusionistic and fictive in favor of the literal, there was a movement away from painterly and toward sculptural concerns. [[Donald Judd]] had started as a painter, and ended as a creator of objects. His seminal essay, "Specific Objects" (published in ''Arts Yearbook 8'', 1965), was a touchstone of theory for the formation of minimalist aesthetics. In this essay, Judd found a starting point for a new territory for American art, and a simultaneous rejection of residual inherited European artistic values. He pointed to evidence of this development in the works of an array of artists active in New York at the time, including [[Jasper Johns]], Dan Flavin and [[Lee Bontecou]]. Of "preliminary" importance for Judd was the work of [[George Earl Ortman]],[http://brooklynrail.org/2006/12/artseen/ortman Brooklynrail.org] who had concretized and distilled painting's forms into blunt, tough, philosophically charged geometries. These Specific Objects inhabited a space not then comfortably classifiable as either painting or sculpture. That the categorical identity of such objects was itself in question, and that they avoided easy association with well-worn and over-familiar conventions, was a part of their value for Judd. This movement was heavily criticised by modernist formalist art critics and historians. Some critics thought minimal art represented a misunderstanding of the modern dialectic of painting and sculpture as defined by critic [[Clement Greenberg]], arguably the dominant American critic of painting in the period leading up to the 1960s. The most notable critique of minimalism was produced by [[Michael Fried]], a formalist critic, who objected to the work on the basis of its "theatricality". In "Art and Objecthood" (published in ''[[Artforum]]'' in June 1967) he declared that the minimal work of art, particularly minimal sculpture, was based on an engagement with the physicality of the spectator. He argued that work like Robert Morris's transformed the act of viewing into a type of [[spectacle]], in which the artifice of the act [[observation]] and the viewer's [[participant Media|participation]] in the work were unveiled. Fried saw this displacement of the viewer's experience from an aesthetic engagement within, to an event outside of the artwork as a failure of minimal art. Fried's essay was immediately challenged by [[postminimalist]] and [[Land art|earth artist]] [[Robert Smithson]] in a letter to the editor in the October issue of ''[[Artforum]]''. Smithson stated the following: "What Fried fears most is the [[consciousness]] of what he is doing--namely being himself theatrical." In addition to the already mentioned [[Robert Morris (artist)|Robert Morris]], [[Frank Stella]], [[Carl Andre]], [[Robert Ryman]] and [[Donald Judd]] other minimal artists include: [[Robert Mangold]], [[Larry Bell (artist)|Larry Bell]], [[Dan Flavin]], [[Sol LeWitt]], [[Ronald Bladen]], [[Agnes Martin]], [[Jo Baer]], [[Paul Mogensen]], [[Ronald Davis]], [[Charles Hinman]], [[David Novros]], [[Brice Marden]], [[Blinky Palermo]], [[John McCracken (artist)|John McCracken]], [[Ad Reinhardt]], [[Fred Sandback]], [[Richard Serra]], [[Tony Smith (sculptor)|Tony Smith]], [[Patricia Johanson]], and [[Anne Truitt]]. [[Ad Reinhardt]], actually an artist of the [[Abstract expressionism|Abstract Expressionist]] generation, but one whose [[reductionism|reductive]] nearly all-black paintings seemed to anticipate minimalism, had this to say about the value of a reductive approach to art: "The more stuff in it, the busier the work of art, the worse it is. More is less. Less is more. The eye is a menace to clear sight. The laying bare of oneself is obscene. Art begins with the getting rid of nature."''Art as Art: The Selected Writings of Ad Reinhardt'' (New York: Viking Press, 1975):{{Page needed|date=November 2011}} {{ISBN|978-0-520-07670-9}}. Reinhardt's remark directly addresses and contradicts [[Hans Hofmann]]'s regard for nature as the source of his own abstract expressionist paintings. In a famous exchange between Hofmann and [[Jackson Pollock]] as told by [[Lee Krasner]] in an [http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/oralhistories/transcripts/krasne64.htm interview with Dorothy Strickler] (1964-11-02) for the Smithsonian Institution [[Archives of American Art]].[http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/oralhistories/transcripts/krasne64.htm Lee Krasner, Archives of American Art] In Krasner's words, "When I brought [[Hans Hofmann|Hofmann]] up to meet Pollock and see his work which was before we moved here, Hofmann's reaction was — one of the questions he asked Jackson was, ''do you work from nature?'' There were no still lifes around or models around and Jackson's answer was, ''I am nature.'' And Hofmann's reply was, ''Ah, but if you work by heart, you will repeat yourself.'' To which Jackson did not reply at all." The meeting between Pollock and Hofmann took place in 1942. ==Footnotes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Minimalism}} * [http://www.dossena.org/tiziano/arte/arte_diabeacon.html Article on Minimalist Art at the Dia Beacon Museum] "Dia Beacon", Tiziano Thomas Dossena, Bridge Apulia USA N.9, 2003 * [http://www2.tate.org.uk/archivejourneys/reisehtml/mov_minimalism.htm Tate, Definition of Minimal Art] * [http://www.tate.org.uk/learn/online-resources/glossary/m/minimalism Tate Glossary: Minimalism] * [http://www.moma.org/collection/theme.php?theme_id=10459 MoMA, Art terms ''Minimalism''] {{Avant-garde}} {{Minimal art}} {{Modernism}} {{Western art movements}} {{Geometric abstraction}} [[Category:Contemporary art]] [[Category:Modern art]] [[Category:Abstract art]] [[Category:Western art]] [[Category:Minimalism| ]]

'''Moral enhancement''' <ref name="Douglas 2008">Douglas, T. (2008). [http://doi.org/10.1111/j.1468-5930.2008.00412.x Moral enhancement]. ''Journal of applied philosophy, 25''(3): 228–245. doi:10.1111/j.1468-5930.2008.00412.x</ref> (abbreviated ME<ref name = "Persson & Savulescu 2016">Persson, I., & Savulescu, J. (2016). [http://doi.org/10.1007/s12152-016-9274-7 Enharrisment: A reply to John Harris about moral enhancement]. ''Neuroethics, 9''(3), 275-277. doi:10.1007/s12152-016-9274-7</ref>), also called '''moral bioenhancement''' (abbreviated MBE<ref>Rakić, V., & Wiseman, H. (2018). [http://doi.org/10.1111/bioe.12415 Different games of moral bioenhancement]. ''Bioethics, 32''(2), 103-110. doi:10.1111/bioe.12415</ref>), is the use of biomedical technology to morally improve people. MBE is a recent topic in [[neuroethics]], involving the [[ethics]] of [[neuroscience]] as well as the neuroscience of ethics. After Thomas Douglas introduced the concept in 2008,<ref name="Douglas 2008" /> its merits have been widely debated in academic [[bioethics]] literature.<ref name = "Specker et al 2014">Specker, J., Focquaert, F., Raus, K., Sterckx, S., & Schermer, M. (2014). [http://doi.org/10.1186/1472-6939-15-67 The ethical desirability of moral bioenhancement: a review of reasons]. ''BMC medical ethics, 15''(67). doi:10.1186/1472-6939-15-67</ref><ref name = "Paulo et al 2017">Paulo, N. & Bublitz, J.C. (2017). [http://doi.org/10.1007/s11245-017-9492-6 How (not) to argue for moral enhancement: reflections on a decade of debate]. ''Topoi'', 1-15. doi:10.1007/s11245-017-9492-6</ref> Since then,<ref>Persson, I., & Savulescu, J. (2008). [http://doi.org/10.1111/j.1468-5930.2008.00410.x The perils of cognitive enhancement and the urgent imperative to enhance the moral character of humanity]. ''Journal of applied philosophy, 25''(3), 162-177. doi:10.1111/j.1468-5930.2008.00410.x</ref> [[Ingmar Persson]] and [[Julian Savulescu]] have been the most vocal MBE supporters.<ref name = "Persson & Savulescu 2016" /><ref name = "Persson et al 2012a">Persson, I., & Savulescu, J. (2012a). ''Unfit for the future: The need for moral enhancement.'' New York: Oxford University Press.</ref><ref name = "Persson et al 2012b">Savulescu, J., & Persson, I. (2012b). [https://philosophynow.org/issues/91/Moral_Enhancement Moral enhancement]. ''Philosophy now, 91'', 6-8.</ref><ref>Savulescu, J., & Persson, I. (2012c). [http://doi.org/10.5840/monist201295321 Moral enhancement, freedom and the God machine]. ''The monist, 95''(3), 399. doi:10.5840/monist201295321</ref><ref>Persson, I., & Savulescu, J. (2014). [http://doi.org/10.1136/medethics-2013-101796 Reply to commentators on Unfit for the Future]. ''Journal of medical ethics, 41''(4), 348-352. doi:10.1136/medethics-2013-101796</ref> Much of the debate over MBE has focused on their 2012 book supporting it, ''Unfit for the Future? The Need for Moral Enhancement.''<ref name = "Persson et al 2012a" />
==Defining moral enhancement==
Moral enhancement in general is sometimes distinguished from MBE specifically, such that ME includes any means of moral improvement while MBE only involves biomedical interventions.<ref name = "Raus et al 2014">Raus, K., Focquaert, F., Schermer, M., Specker, J., & Sterckx, S. (2014). [http://doi.org/10.1007/s12152-014-9205-4 On defining moral enhancement: a clarificatory taxonomy]. ''Neuroethics, 7''(3), 263-273. doi:10.1007/s12152-014-9205-4</ref> For example, Persson and Savulescu have cited [[moral education]] as an example of socially accepted non-biomedical moral enhancement.<ref name = "Persson et al 2012b" />
Some also distinguish invasive from non-invasive, intended from resultant, treatment-focused from enhancement-focused, capability-improving from behavior-improving, and passive from active ME interventions.<ref name = "Raus et al 2014" /> [[Vojin Rakić]] has distinguished voluntary from compulsory MBE, claiming that the former is justifiable even if the latter is not.<ref name = "Rakic 2014a">Rakić, V. (2014a). [http://doi.org/10.1136/medethics-2012-100700 Voluntary moral enhancement and the survival-at-any-cost bias]. ''Journal of medical ethics, 40''(4), 246-250. doi:10.1136/medethics-2012-100700</ref><ref>Rakić, V. (2014b). [http://doi.org/10.1080/15265161.2014.889249 Voluntary moral bioenhancement is a solution to Sparrow's concerns]. ''The American journal of bioethics, 14''(4), 37-38. doi:10.1080/15265161.2014.889249</ref>
==Arguments in favor==
Douglas originally suggested MBE as a counter-example to what he called the "[[bioconservative]] thesis," which claims that [[human enhancement]] is immoral even if it is feasible. He argued that enhancements to reduce "counter-moral" racist and aggressive emotional reactions would at least be morally permissible.<ref name = "Douglas 2008" />
[[Mark Alan Walker]] proposed a "Genetic Virtue Project" to genetically enhance moral traits. Given that personality traits are heritable, and some traits are moral while others are immoral, he suggested increasing moral traits while reducing immoral ones through [[genetic engineering]].<ref>Walker, M. (2009, September). [http://doi.org/10.2990/28_2_27 Enhancing genetic virtue: A project for twenty-first century humanity?]. ''Politics and the life sciences, 28''(2), 27-47. doi:10.2990/28_2_27</ref>
Based on the fact that human technological progress has advanced faster than human moral psychology can adapt through evolution, Persson & Savulescu point out that humans' capability to cause large-scale destruction has increased exponentially. However, given that humans tend to care only about their immediate acquaintances and circumstances instead of thinking on a larger scale, they are vulnerable to [[Tragedy of the commons|tragedies of the commons]] like climate change and to technologies like nuclear weapons which pose an [[existential threat]] to humanity. Given that moral education and [[liberal democracy]] are insufficient, MBE is needed at least as a supplementary method to solve these problems.<ref name = "Persson et al 2012a" /><ref name = "Persson et al 2012b" />
==Criticism==
Central issues debated in the MBE literature include whether there is an urgent need for MBE, a sufficient consensus on the definition of morality, some technically feasible and ethically permissible interventions to carry out MBE, no violation of consent in those interventions, and no harmful social side-effects that they produce.<ref name = "Specker et al 2014" />
===Sufficiency of non-biomedical methods===
Terri Murray disputed the claim by Persson & Savulescu that political will and moral education are insufficient to address the major problems facing humanity, claiming that Persson & Savulescu unjustly reify moral dispositions in biology.<ref name = "Murray 2012">Murray, T. (2012). [https://philosophynow.org/issues/93/The_Incoherence_of_Moral_Bioenhancement The incoherence of moral bioenhancement]. ''Philosophy now, 93'', 19-21.</ref>
===Ethical basis of moral enhancement===
Since the nature of morality has historically caused wide disagreements, several authors have questioned whether it is possible to come up with a sufficiently widely accepted ethical basis for MBE, especially with respect to what qualities should be enhanced.<ref name = "Paulo et al 2017" /><ref>Beck, B. (2015). [http://doi.org/10.1111/bioe.12090 Conceptual and practical problems of moral enhancement]. ''Bioethics, 29''(4), 233-240. doi:10.1111/bioe.12090</ref>
===Feasibility===
MBE proponents have been accused of being too speculative, overstating the capabilities of future interventions and describing unrealistic scenarios like enhancing "all of humanity."<ref name = "Specker et al 2014" /> One literature review assessed the evidence on seven interventions cited by MBE proponents, finding all of them ineffective.<ref>Dubljević, V., & Racine, E. (2017, May 15). [http://doi.org/10.1111/bioe.12355 Moral enhancement meets normative and empirical reality: Assessing the practical feasibility of moral enhancement neurotechnologies]. ''Bioethics, 31''(5), 338-348. doi:10.1111/bioe.12355</ref>
===Role of individual choice===
Other authors have suggested that unless MBE is based on an individual's choice, it cannot truly be called "moral" enhancement because personal choice is the basis of ethics.<ref name = "Rakic 2014a" /><ref name = "Murray 2012" /><ref>Melo‐Martin, I., & Salles, A. (2015). [http://doi.org/10.1111/bioe.12100 Moral bioenhancement: much ado about nothing?]. ''Bioethics, 29''(4), 223-232. doi:10.1111/bioe.12100</ref>
===Social equality===
If MBE is more effective for enhancing people that are already moral, then it could increase the gap between moral and immoral people, increasing social inequality.<ref>Ram-Tiktin, E. (2014). [http://doi.org/10.1080/15265161.2014.889246 The possible effects of moral bioenhancement on political privileges and fair equality of opportunity]. ''The American journal of bioethics, 14''(4), 43-44. doi:10.1080/15265161.2014.889246</ref> Also, if MBE makes some people morally better, it could unfairly raise the moral standards for everyone else.<ref>Archer, A. (2016). [http://doi.org/10.1111/bioe.12251 Moral enhancement and those left behind]. ''Bioethics, 30''(7), 500-510. doi:10.1111/bioe.12251</ref> ==See also== * [[Neuroethics#Key issues|Key issues in neuroethics]] * [[Human enhancement]] * [[Cognitive enhancement]] * [[Transhumanism]] == References == {{Reflist}}

'''Morisita's overlap index''', named after [[:ja:森下正明|Masaaki Morisita]], is a [[dispersion (statistics)|statistical measure of dispersion]] of individuals in a population. It is used to compare overlap among [[Sample (statistics)|samples]] (Morisita 1959). This formula is based on the assumption that increasing the size of the samples will increase the diversity because it will include different habitats (i.e. different faunas).
Formula:
: <math>C_D= \frac{2\sum_{i=1}^S x_i y_i }{(D_x + D_y) XY }</math>
: ''x''<sub>''i''</sub> is the number of times species ''i'' is represented in the total ''X'' from one sample. : ''y''<sub>''i''</sub> is the number of times species ''i'' is represented in the total ''Y'' from another sample. : ''D''<sub>''x''</sub> and ''D''<sub>''y''</sub> are the [[Simpson's index]] values for the ''x'' and ''y'' samples respectively. : ''S'' is the number of unique species
''C''<sub>''D''</sub> = 0 if the two samples do not overlap in terms of species, and ''C''<sub>''D''</sub> = 1 if the species occur in the same proportions in both samples.{{citation needed|date=February 2012}}
Horn's modification of the index is (Horn 1966): :<math>C_H= \frac{ 2 \sum_{i=1}^S x_i y_i }{ \left( {\sum_{i=1}^S x_i^2 \over X^2} + {\sum_{i=1}^S y_i^2 \over Y^2} \right) X Y } \,.</math>
== References ==
* Morisita, M. (1959). "Measuring of the dispersion and analysis of distribution patterns". ''Memoires of the Faculty of Science'', [[Kyushu University]], Series E. Biology. 2: 215–235. * Morisita, M. (1962). "''I''<sub>''δ''</sub>-Index, A Measure of Dispersion of Individuals". ''Researches on Population Ecology'', 4 (1), 1–7. * Horn, H. S. (1966). Measurement of "Overlap" in comparative ecological studies. ''The American Naturalist" 100:419-424. {{jstor|2459242}} * Linton, L. R.; Davies, Ronald W.; Wrona, F. J. (1981) "Resource Utilization Indices: An Assessment", ''Journal of Animal Ecology'', 50 (1), 283-292 {{jstor|4045}} * Ricklefs, Robert E.; Lau, Michael (1980) "Bias and Dispersion of Overlap Indices: Results of Some Monte Carlo Simulations", ''Ecology'', 61 (5), 1019-1024 {{jstor|1936817}} * Garratt, Michael W.; Steinhorst, R. Kirk (1976). "Testing for significance of Morisita’s, Horn’s and related measures of overlap". '' American Midland Naturalist'' 96 (1), 245-251 {{jstor|2424587}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100324130601/http://www.tnstate.edu/ganter/B412%20Ch%2015%2616%20CommMetric.html Community Metrics] * [http://www.morisita.or.jp Masaaki MORISITA]

{{merge to|Samdani Art Foundation|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Nadia Samdani | image = Nadia Samdani.jpg | image_size = 200px | occupation = Art collector, philanthropist | nationality = British-Bangladeshi }}
'''Nadia Samdani''' (born 12 December 1981) is a British-born Bangladeshi philanthropist, art patron and collector. She is the co-founder and president of the Samdani Art Foundation, and director of the Dhaka Art Summit. She is also the director of Golden Harvest Group, a leading Bangladeshi conglomerate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goldenharvestbd.com/managemet/|title=Directors Profile – Golden Harvest|website=www.goldenharvestbd.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.samdani.com.bd/our-team/|title=OUR TEAM|website=Samdani Art Foundation}}</ref>
== Philanthropy == Nadia and her husband Rajeeb Samdani were donors for the 56th International Biennale di Venezia in 2015, supporting projects by [[Naeem Mohaiemen]] and Raqs Media Collective in the main Biennale exhibition: All the World's Futures. They have also supported [[Naeem Mohaiemen]]'s first European Solo exhibition "Prisoners of Shothik Itihash" at [[Kunsthalle Basel]], curated by [[Adam Szymczyk]] in 2014, and Bangladeshi-British artist Rana Begum's first major institutional solo exhibition at The Parasol Unit in 2016. The support took place under their non-profit engagement, Samdani Art Foundation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Show me the money|last=Gareth|first=Harris|date=2 May 2015|newspaper=Financial Times|quote=The Dhaka-based Samdani Art Foundation, for instance, is sponsoring the Bangladeshi artist Naeem Mohaiemen and Raqs Media Collective in the main biennale exhibition ( All the World's Futures )}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://newagebd.net/108205/saf-to-promote-2-projects-at-venice-biennale/|title=New Age – SAF to promote 2 projects at Venice biennale|date=3 April 2015|publisher=Newagebd.net|accessdate=14 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kunsthallebasel.ch/en/exhibition/prisoners-of-shothik-itihash/|title=Prisoners of Shothik Itihash • Kunsthalle Basel|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://parasol-unit.org/whats-on/rana-begum-space/|title=Rana Begum: The Space Between - Parasol unit|publisher=}}</ref>
Nadia Samdani founded the [[Samdani Art Foundation]] in 2011 along with her husband Rajeeb Samdani. Nadia acts as the President of the foundation, which supports the work of Bangladeshi and South Asian contemporary artists and architects to increase their international exposure. As part of the initiative, the foundation runs the bi-annual Samdani Art and Architecture Awards which bring to light, the work of emerging Bangladeshi contemporary artists and architects.The Foundations other on-going initiatives include the Samdani Artist-Led Initiatives Forum and Samdani Seminars.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://frieze.com/article/how-see-somewhere-else-4th-dhaka-art-summit|title=How to See from Somewhere Else – the 4th Dhaka Art Summit|website=frieze.com}}</ref><ref>https://independent-collectors.com/interviews/nadia-rajeeb-samdani-dhaka-art-summit/ Nadia and Rajeeb Samdani</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thedailystar.net/lifestyle/news-flash/samdani-architecture-award-winner-announced-1464085|title=Samdani Architecture Award winner announced|date=19 September 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://artreview.com/news/news_5_feb_18_mizanur_rahman_chowdhury_wins_samdani_art_award/|title=Mizanur Rahman Chowdhury wins Samdani Art Award / ArtReview|first=Site|last=name|website=artreview.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://theartling.com/en/artzine/2018/02/05/re-examinations-on-the-function-of-art-dhaka-art-summit-2018/|title=Re-Examinations on the Function of Art: Dhaka Art Summit 2018 - The Artling|website=The Artling}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/uncategorized/2015/04/09/samdani-seminars-art-in-body-steps|title=Samdani Seminars: Art in body steps|date=9 April 2015|publisher=}}</ref> [[File:Nadia Samdani with the President of Switzerland Mr. Alain Berset at the Dhaka Art Summit 2018.jpg|thumb|Mr. Alain Berset, the President of Switzerland visited Dhaka Art Summit on 7th February 2018 during his visit to Bangladesh.]] Nadia and Rajeeb Samdani have announced to open Srihatta—Samdani Art Centre and Sculpture Park in late 2018. The centre is being designed by Kashef Mahboob Chowdhury, who won the [[Aga Khan Award for Architecture|Aga Khan Award]] in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/abinlot/2017/05/11/srihatta-samdani-art-centre-and-sculpture-park-to-open-late-2018-in-bangladesh/#7005cee54578|title=Srihatta: Samdani Art Centre And Sculpture Park To Open Late 2018 In Bangladesh|first=Ann|last=Binlot|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/2017/05/12/samdani-art-foundation-unveils-plans-and-announces-programming-for-first-permanent-space/|title=Samdani Art Foundation Unveils Plans for First Permanent Space|first=Sarah|last=Douglas|date=12 May 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://culture360.asef.org/news-events/srihatta-samdani-art-centre-takes-shape-bangladesh|title=Srihatta-Samdani Art Centre takes shape in Bangladesh - ASEF culture360|website=culture360.asef.org}}</ref>
=== Dhaka Art Summit === Dhaka Art Summit is the most successful initiative Nadia Samdani has established in 2012. The Summit takes place every two years at the Bangladesh Shilpakala Academy in collaboration with the Ministry of Cultural Affairs, People's Republic of Bangladesh and is said to be the largest international event for South Asian art. The 4th edition of the Summit took place between 2 and 10 February 2018, receiving a footfall of 317,000, including over 1,200 international visitors and the President of Switzerland, Mr. Alain Berset.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/800895/bangladeshs-first-art-summit-ends-on-a-high|title=Bangladesh’s First Art Summit Ends on a High - Artinfo|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/beyond-business/collector-s-corner-112030300055_1.html|title=Collector's corner|first=Gargi|last=Gupta|date=3 March 2012|publisher=|via=Business Standard}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/art/dhaka-art-summit-lauds-bangladesh-s-cultural-heritage-1.702303|title=Dhaka Art Summit lauds Bangladesh’s cultural heritage|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saatsaatharts.org/dhaka-art-summit-2016|title=SAAT SAATH ARTS|website=www.saatsaatharts.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://gulfnews.com/culture/arts/300-artists-10-exhibitions-at-dhaka-art-summit-1.2166088#.WnMO1lTH-wI.hotmail|title=300 artists, 10 exhibitions at Dhaka Art Summit|first=Nilima PathakSpecial to Weekend|last=Review|date=31 January 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://ocula.com/magazine/reports/into-the-blue--dhaka-art-summit-2018/|title=Into the Blue: Dhaka Art Summit 2018 - Ocula|date=14 June 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/foreign-affairs/2018/02/04/swiss-president-dhaka/|title=Swiss President Alain Berset in Dhaka|date=4 February 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
== Contribution ==
Nadia Samdani is a member of [[Tate]]'s South Asia Acquisitions Committee, Tate's International Council, [[Art Dubai]]'s Advisory Council, [[Alserkal Avenue]]'s Programming Committee, Parasol Unit's International Committee and is one of the founding members of [[Harvard University]]'s Lakshmi Mittal South Asia Institute's Arts Advisory Council. She is also the Vice- President of [[Alliance Française]] de Dhaka.<ref name="dhakacourier.com.bd">{{cite web|url=http://www.dhakacourier.com.bd/rajeeb-and-nadia-samdani-among-top-art-collectors-in-the-world/|title=Rajeeb and Nadia Samdani among top art collectors in the world|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artdubai.ae/committees/|title=Committees - Art Dubai|first=Art|last=Dubai|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abudhabicityinfo.com/news/pr_Alserkal_Avenue_Announces_New_Homegrown_Programme_Featuring.aspx|title=Alserkal Avenue Announces New Homegrown Programme Featuring Premieres During Dubai Art Week 2015 - Abu Dhabi Press Releases, News, Events, Metro, Immigration, Visas, Travel, Tourism, Sports, Education, Jobs, Employment, City Talk, Real Estate, Properties & more|website=www.abudhabicityinfo.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://mittalsouthasiainstitute.harvard.edu/2015/12/sai-forms-arts-advisory-council/|title=Founding members form South Asian Arts Council • Lakshmi Mittal South Asia Institute|date=9 December 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.afdhaka.org/executive_committee_and_constitution.php|title=Executive Committee & Constitution|website=www.afdhaka.org}}</ref>
Nadia has contributed numerous articles about the role of the collector and arts patron within the international art scene for publications including, [[Art Asia Pacific]], and leading business and financial daily ''[[Live Mint]]''. She has spoken about collecting at many international art fairs and universities, including: the [[University of California]], [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]]; [[Art Basel]] Hong Kong; [[Frieze Art Fair]], London; the [[India Art Fair]]; and the 2nd edition of the Private Museum Conference. In 2017, Nadia also contributed to [[UNESCO]]'s Global Report on Monitoring the 2005 Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artasiapacific.com/Magazine/Almanac2013|title=ArtAsiaPacific: Almanac2013|website=artasiapacific.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.livemint.com/Leisure/9xY5KUtETFmE4TPKqhaj4L/Collecting-Art-Is-Deeply-Personal.html|title=Collecting Art Is Deeply Personal|first=Nadia|last=Samdani|date=22 February 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dk1ArswjsxM|title=South Asian Art: A Conversation between Nadia and Rajeeb Samdani and Chitra Ganesh|first=|last=Institute for South Asia Studies UC Berkeley|date=3 May 2018|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.artbasel.com/events/detail/6697/Artworld-Talk-The-Art-of-the-Commission-Funding-Cultural-Production|title=Artworld Talk - The Art of the Commission: Funding Cultural Production - Events - Art Basel|first=Art|last=Basel|website=Art Basel}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-268590|title=Nadia Samdani participates in Speaker's Forum, India Art Fair|date=11 February 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.larryslist.com/artmarket/features/highlights-from-the-second-edition-of-the-private-museum-conference/|title=Highlights from the Second Edition of the Private Museum Conference|website=www.larryslist.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/sseas.html?event_ID=116608&date=2018-04-27|title=South Asian Art - Past, Present, Future|website=events.berkeley.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.unesco.org/creativity/sites/creativity/files/concept_note_global_report_2017_0.pdf |title=Report |website=en.unesco.org |format=PDF}}</ref>
== Art collection == Nadia Samdani is a second generation art collector and began her own collection at the age of 22. She collects both Bangladeshi and international art. Nadia and her husband Rajeeb Samdani's collection includes over 2000 modern and contemporary artworks. South Asian and diaspora collection highlights include works by: Anish Kapoor; Gaganendranath Tagore; Abanindranath Tagore; Rabindranath Tagore; Huma Bhabha; Naeem Mohaiemen; Rana Begum; Raqs Media Collective; Shilpa Gupta; Shahzia Sikander; Novera Ahmed; and Zarina Hashmi, etc. International collection highlights include works by: Lynda Benglis; Chris Ofili; Alighiero Boetti; Paul Klee; Ettore Spalletti; Cindy Sherman; Marina Abramovic; Ai Weiwei; Pawel Althamer; Mona Hatoum; Philippe Parreno; Dominique Gonzalez-Foerster; Cardiff and Miller; and Anthony McCall.<ref name="dhakacourier.com.bd"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://museumnetwork.sothebys.com/article/breaking-new-ground-for-contemporary-art-in-bangladesh|title=Breaking New Ground for Contemporary Art in Bangladesh|date=6 February 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.samdani.com.bd/our-collection/|title=OUR COLLECTION|website=Samdani Art Foundation}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/top200/nadia-and-rajeeb-samdani/|title=Nadia and Rajeeb Samdani -|website=ARTnews}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://independent-collectors.com/interviews/nadia-rajeeb-samdani-dhaka-art-summit/|title=Nadia & Rajeeb Samdani - Independent Collectors|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.architecturaldigest.in/content/samdani-residence-art/|title=In the fairytale home of the Samdanis, the art is the hero|website=Architectural Design - Interior Design - Home Decoration Magazine - AD India}}</ref>
Artworks from their collection have travelled to major exhibitions, such as: Documenta14 (2017); Shanghai Biennale (2017); Office for Contemporary Art, Norway (2016); Centre Pompidou, Paris (2015); Kunstsammlung Nordhrhein, Düsseldorf (2016); Gwangju Biennale, South Korea (2014); and the Kochi-Muziris Biennale, India (2014), etc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.documenta14.de/en/artists/13547/lala-rukh|title=Lala Rukh|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.oca.no/programme/notations/the-missing-one.1|title=The Missing One: Programme: OCA|first=Dorian|last=Moore|website=www.oca.no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=29. 9. 2015 |url=https://www.spikeartmagazine.com/en/image-article/dominique-gonzalez-foerster-1887-2058-centre-pompidou |title=Dominique Gonzalez-Foerster, 1887-2058 @ Centre Pompidou |publisher=Spike Art Magazine |date= |accessdate=14 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kunstsammlung.de/en/discover/exhibition-archive/2016.html|title=Kunstsammlung NRW: 2016|first=internetagentur bonn köln sunzinet typo3 und reddot|last=programmmierung|website=www.kunstsammlung.de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.samdani.com.bd/blog/2017/4/18/huma-muljis-work-at-gwangju-biennale|title=SAF AROUND THE WORLD: HUMA MULJI'S LOST AND FOUND AT GWANGJU BIENNALE|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="kochimuzirisbiennale.org">{{cite web|url=http://kochimuzirisbiennale.org/project-support/|title=Project Support - Kochi-Muziris Biennale 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
== Personal life ==
Nadia is married to Rajeeb Samdani who is the Managing Director of Golden Harvest Group, Co-Founder and Trustee of the Samdani Art Foundation and Dhaka Art Summit, and Chairman of Gulf International Finance Limited, UAE. They have three daughters: Radyna, Alvina and Maya. The couple is well known for their local and international art collection as well as their art philanthropy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hellopakistanmag.com/hello-pakistan/the-creatives-behind-dhaka-art-summit/|title=Nadia & Rajeeb Samdani: The Creatives Behind Dhaka Art Summit -|date=3 June 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
== Acknowledgement ==
Nadia and her husband Rajeeb have received several awards for their philanthropy. They were the first South Asians to receive the Montblanc de la Culture Arts Patronage award in 2017. They have also been recognised in Artnews's Top 200 Collectors list in 2015, 2016 and 2017, in ArtReview's Power 100 list in 2015, 2016 and 2017, and in ArtNet News's World's Top 100 Art Collectors in 2016. In 2018, Nadia received a "Recognition of Merit" award in the category of outstanding entrepreneur and innovator from the Rotary Club of Dhaka North during their celebration of 50 Golden Years. She has also received recognition as the "Most Inspiring Female in Promoting Art" at the 2018 Women in Leadership Fest in Dhaka.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.harpersbazaararabia.com/art/news/montblanc-de-la-culture-arts-patronage-award-presented-in-dubai|title=Montblanc De La Culture Arts Patronage Award Presented In Dubai|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/top200year/2015/|title=2015 Archives|website=ARTnews}}</ref><ref name="artreview1">{{cite web|url=https://artreview.com/power_100/nadia_rajeeb_samdani/|title=Nadia & Rajeeb Samdani / Power 100 / ArtReview|first=Site|last=name|website=artreview.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.artnet.com/market/worlds-top-100-art-collectors-part-two-513953|title=The artnet News Index: The World's Top 100 Art Collectors for 2016, Part Two - artnet News|date=15 June 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://artreview.com/power_100/|title=Power 100 / ArtReview|first=Site|last=name|website=artreview.com}}</ref><ref name="artreview1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theindependentbd.com/arcprint/details/145504/2018-04-12 |title=Rotary Club marks golden jubilee |publisher=theindependentbd.com |date=12 April 2018 |accessdate=14 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/dhaka/2018/03/11/wil-fest-2018-celebrates-inspiring-women/|title=WIL Fest 2018 celebrates inspiring women|date=10 March 2018|publisher=}}</ref> {{clear}}

{{other uses}} {{one source|date=May 2010}} The '''orgasmatron''' is a fictional electromechanical device that appears in the [[1973 in film|1973 movie]] ''[[Sleeper (1973 film)|Sleeper]]'', which also shows the effects of a related device, an '''orgasmic orb'''. Similar devices have appeared in other fictional works. The term has also been applied to a non-fictional device capable of triggering an orgasm-like sensation using [[electrode]]s implanted at the lower spine.
Author [[Christopher Turner]] has suggested that the orgasmatron was a parody of [[Wilhelm Reich]]'s [[orgone]] accumulator.<ref name=slate>{{cite news |first=Peter D. |last=Kramer |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2297527/ |title=The Great Proselytizer of Orgasm |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date=June 27, 2011 |accessdate=July 9, 2011 |quote=Orgasmatron is Woody Allen's name, in Sleeper, for a parody of Reich's orgone accumulator, a telephone booth-sized plywood and metal box said to store a healing and enlivening force. }}</ref><ref name=guardian>{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Turner |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/jul/08/wilhelm-reich-free-love-orgasmatron |title=Wilhelm Reich: the man who invented free love |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=July 8, 2011 |accessdate=July 9, 2011 |quote=Woody Allen parodied it in Sleeper (1973), giving it the immortal nickname the "Orgasmatron". }}</ref>
==In ''Sleeper'' (1973)== The orgasmatron is a fictional device in the fictional future society of 2173 in the [[Woody Allen]] movie ''[[Sleeper (1973 film)|Sleeper]]''. It is a large cylinder big enough to contain one or two people. The orgasmatron was made by decorating an [[elevator]] in the home where the movie was filmed. Once entered, it contains some (otherwise undescribed) future technology that rapidly induces [[orgasm]]s. This is required, as almost all people in the ''Sleeper'' universe are [[impotent]] or [[hypoactive sexual desire disorder|frigid]], although males of Italian descent are considered the least impotent of all groups.
The main character Miles Monroe, played by Allen, is being hunted by the police as being [[subversive]] to security of the state, and attempts to hide in it, thinking it is a closet. He is discovered there, and easily captured in a daze, with a sheepish smile on his face.
Another related device, an orb, also appears in this movie. It is a silver-colored sphere about the size of a [[grapefruit]] that contains some (otherwise undescribed) future technology. When the orb is touched by a human, it induces pleasurable sensations. In a scene where Miles impersonates a [[robot]]ic servant, he is ordered by the hostess to pass the orb among the guests. Unlike the robot he is imitating, he is not immune to the effects of the orb. Much physical humor results from his reaction to firmly holding this device, which party participants only lightly caress.
Later on, they encounter a [[gay]] male couple, one of whom offers Miles a "hit off the orb". Miles reports that he's "cool" and does not need to indulge. It appears the effect of the orb is more like social [[alcoholic beverage|drinking]] or [[drug|drug use]], pleasurable rather than orgasmic.
==Similar concepts== Similar devices are:
===In ''Barbarella'' (1964)=== (Referred to in both the [[Barbarella (comics)|comic]] and 1968 [[Barbarella (film)|film]]—the description below refers to the film.)
The device has been invented by Dr. Durand-Durand, the evil antagonist in ''[[Barbarella (film)|Barbarella]]''. Instead of being called an Orgasmatron, Durand-Durand refers to it as the Excessive Machine. It resembles a clamshell that once grasping the passenger's entire body below the neck, gently (at first) and pleasurably massages the passenger by flexing its upper half with a wave-like motion from right to left. The lid is made of long, rigid rod-like paddles that lie in a row, side by side. The paddles themselves each have one end at the bottom of the lid, near the joint of the Excessive Machine's "clamshell", and the other end moves freely. Because the paddles are not glued or welded together but instead move together, and because the paddles pivot around the "clamshell" joint and move parallel to the [[sagittal plane]], they can have this wave-like motion. It is operated from a [[Keyboard instrument|keyboard]] resembling that used to control a large [[organ (music)|organ]]. By properly manipulating the keys the operator may induce great sexual pleasure in the victim, sufficient to cause death by [[orgasm]]. In one of the final scenes of the movie the evil opponent is torturing Barbarella with the pleasures of this machine, during which she vocalises extensively ("oh", "ooh", "ahh", etc.). But in the end the machine overloads and is destroyed, while she survives, and feels rather well.
See [[Magic Mountain (1973)]] by Jadorowski for another orgasmatron.
===In ''Flesh Gordon'' (1974)=== In the 1974 film ''[[Flesh Gordon]]'', a [[ribaldry|ribald]] parody of the science fiction adventures of [[Flash Gordon]], the villain "Emperor Wang" directs a "sex ray" at Earth which causes the planet's inhabitants to become uncontrollably sexually aroused.
===In ''Orgasmatron'' (1986)=== ''[[Orgasmatron (album)|Orgasmatron]]'' is the seventh album by the British band [[Motörhead]], released in 1986. It is the only full Motörhead album to feature [[Pete Gill]] on the [[Drum kit|drums]], although he also played on the four new tracks recorded for the 1984 ''[[No Remorse (Motörhead album)|No Remorse]]'' [[compilation album]].
=== In ''Coneheads'' (1993) === "Senso-rings" were used in the movie ''[[Coneheads]]'' to provide pleasure to the other partner.
=== In ''Demolition Man'' (1993) === John Spartan (played by [[Sylvester Stallone]]) is introduced to an orgasmatron-like device by [[Lenina Huxley|Lt. Lenina Huxley]] ([[Sandra Bullock]]) in the 1993 movie ''[[Demolition Man (film)|Demolition Man]]''. The device is in widespread use in the film's future world, since actual sex ("fluid exchange") has been deemed unsafe and become both illegal and socially taboo.
===In ''Orgazmo'' (1997)=== In ''[[Orgazmo]]'', the "Orgazmorator" was built in the form of an oversized water gun. It was operated by pointing it at a subject and firing. Apparently, it could even generate multiple successive orgasms in a man.
==Non-fictional orgasmatron==
===Surgically implanted devices=== {{see also|Wirehead (science fiction)}}
Discovered serendipitously as a potential side effect of a [[spinal cord stimulator]] used in pain relief, the medical "orgasmatron" device has been judged effective by some recipients, but costs $3,000 and requires surgical insertion of electrodes near the [[spinal cord]]. Invented by Dr. Stuart Meloy in [[Winston-Salem]], the device employs a [[function generator]] manufactured by Advanced Medical Electronics Corporation (AME Corp.). It has been described as being of great potential in treating sexual dysfunction in women.<ref name=ABC>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Living/story?id=235788&|title=Doctor Discovers the 'Orgasmatron'|date=2004-11-09|publisher=ABC|accessdate=2008-10-12|work=ABC}}</ref><ref name="LA Times">{{cite news |title=Call him doctor 'Orgasmatron' |first1=Regina |last1=Nuzzo |url=http://www.latimes.com/la-he-orside11feb11,1,5212599.story?ctrack=1&cset=true |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |location=Los Angeles, CA |oclc=71790328 |date=February 11, 2008 |accessdate=January 29, 2011 |quote=Dr. Stuart Meloy stumbled upon an alternative -- and pleasurable -- use for an electrode stimulation device that treats pain. }}</ref> The device and its inventor were featured in the first episode of the seventh season of the Showtime show ''[[Penn & Teller: Bullshit!]]''

'''Oxygen radical absorbance capacity''' ('''ORAC''') was a method of measuring [[antioxidant]] capacities in biological samples ''[[in vitro]]''.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cao G, Alessio HM, Cutler RG | title = Oxygen-radical absorbance capacity assay for antioxidants | journal = Free Radic. Biol. Med. | volume = 14 | issue = 3 | pages = 303–11 | year = 1993 | pmid = 8458588 | doi = 10.1016/0891-5849(93)90027-R }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Ou B, Hampsch-Woodill M, Prior RL | title = Development and validation of an improved oxygen radical absorbance capacity assay using fluorescein as the fluorescent probe | journal = J. Agric. Food Chem. | volume = 49 | issue = 10 | pages = 4619–26 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11599998 | doi = 10.1021/jf010586o }}</ref> In 2012, stating that no [[physiology|physiological]] proof ''[[in vivo]]'' existed in support of the [[free-radical theory]], ORAC was withdrawn due to absence of correlation between test results and biological activity.<ref name=USDAx>{{cite web |url=http://www.ars.usda.gov/services/docs.htm?docid=15866 |title=Withdrawn: Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC) of Selected Foods, Release 2 (2010) |author= |date=16 May 2012 |work= |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service |accessdate=13 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nutraceuticalsworld.com/issues/2009-03/view_features/new-roles-for-polyphenols/ |title=New Roles for Polyphenols. A 3-Part report on Current Regulations & the State of Science |last1=Gross |first1=P |last2= |first2= |date=2009 |work=Nutraceuticals World |publisher=Rodman Media |accessdate=April 11, 2013}}</ref>
A wide variety of foods were tested using this method, with certain [[spice]]s, [[berries]] and [[legume]]s rated highly in extensive tables once published by the [[United States Department of Agriculture]] (USDA). Alternative measurements include the [[Folin-Ciocalteu reagent]], and the [[Trolox equivalent antioxidant capacity]] assay.
==Method== The [[assay]] measures the oxidative degradation of the fluorescent molecule (either beta-phycoerythrin or [[fluorescein]]) after being mixed with free radical generators such as [[Azo compound|azo-initiator compounds]]. Azo-initiators are considered to produce the [[peroxyl radical]] by heating, which damages the fluorescent molecule, resulting in the loss of fluorescence. [[Antioxidant]]s are considered to protect the fluorescent molecule from the oxidative degeneration. The degree of protection is quantified using a [[fluorometer]]. Fluorescein is currently used most as a fluorescent probe. Equipment that can automatically measure and calculate the capacity is commercially available (Biotek, Roche Diagnostics).
The fluorescent intensity decreases as the oxidative degeneration proceeds, and this intensity is typically recorded for 35 minutes after the addition of the azo-initiator (free radical generator). So far, AAPH (2,2’-azobis(2-amidino-propane) dihydrochloride) is the sole free-radical generator used. The degeneration (or decomposition) of fluorescein is measured as the presence of the antioxidant slows the fluorescence decay. Decay curves (fluorescence intensity vs. time) are recorded and the area between the two decay curves (with or without antioxidant) is calculated. Subsequently, the degree of antioxidant-mediated protection is quantified using the antioxidant [[trolox]] (a vitamin E analogue) as a standard. Different concentrations of trolox are used to make a standard curve, and test samples are compared to this. Results for test samples (foods) have been published as "trolox equivalents" or TEs.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Huang D, Ou B, Prior RL | title = The chemistry behind antioxidant capacity assays | journal = J. Agric. Food Chem. | volume = 53 | issue = 6 | pages = 1841–56 | year = 2005 | pmid = 15769103 | doi = 10.1021/jf030723c }}</ref><ref name="Garrett_2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Garrett AR, Murray BK, Robison RA, O'Neill KL | title = Measuring antioxidant capacity using the ORAC and TOSC assays | journal = Methods Mol. Biol. | volume = 594 | issue = | pages = 251–62 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20072922 | doi = 10.1007/978-1-60761-411-1_17 | series = Methods in Molecular Biology | isbn = 978-1-60761-410-4 }}</ref>
One benefit of using the ORAC method to evaluate substances' antioxidant capacities is that it takes into account samples with and without lag phases of their antioxidant capacities. This is especially beneficial when measuring foods and supplements that contain complex ingredients with various slow- and fast-acting antioxidants, as well as ingredients with combined effects that cannot be precalculated.
Drawbacks of this method are: 1) only antioxidant activity against particular (probably mainly peroxyl) radicals is measured; however, peroxyl radical formation has never been proven; 2) the nature of the damaging reaction is not characterized; 3) there is no evidence that free radicals are involved in this reaction; and 4) there is no evidence that ORAC values have any biological significance following consumption of any food. Moreover, the relationship between ORAC values and a health benefit has not been established.
Resulting from scientific refutation of the physiological significance of ORAC, the USDA, which had been collating and publishing ORAC data for more than a decade, withdrew its web publication of ORAC values for common American foods in May 2012.<ref name=USDAx/>
Several modified ORAC methods have been proposed. Most of them employ the same principle (i.e. measurement of AAPH-radical mediated damage of fluorescein); however, ORAC-EPR, electron paramagnetic resonance-based ORAC method directly measures the decrease of AAPH-radical level by the scavenging action of the antioxidant substance.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kohri S, Fujii H, Oowada S, Endoh N, Sueishi Y, Kusakabe M, Shimmei M, Kotake Y | title = An oxygen radical absorbance capacity-like assay that directly quantifies the antioxidant's scavenging capacity against AAPH-derived free radicals | journal = Anal. Biochem. | volume = 386 | issue = 2 | pages = 167–71 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19150323 | doi = 10.1016/j.ab.2008.12.022 }}</ref>
==Regulatory guidance== In the following discussion, the term "antioxidant" refers mainly to non-nutrient compounds in foods, such as [[polyphenol]]s, which have antioxidant capacity'' [[in vitro]]'', so provide an artificial index of antioxidant strength—the ORAC measurement.
Other than for dietary antioxidant vitamins—[[vitamin A]], [[vitamin C]] and [[vitamin E]]—no food compounds have been proved with antioxidant efficacy ''[[in vivo]]''.{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} Accordingly, regulatory agencies such as the [[Food and Drug Administration]] of the United States and the [[European Food Safety Authority]] (EFSA) have published guidance forbidding food product labels to claim or imply an antioxidant benefit when no such physiological evidence exists.<ref>[https://www.fda.gov/food/guidanceregulation/guidancedocumentsregulatoryinformation/ucm063064.htm Guidance for Industry, Food Labeling; Nutrient Content Claims; Definition for "High Potency" and Definition for "Antioxidant" for Use in Nutrient Content Claims for Dietary Supplements and Conventional Foods] U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Food and Drug Administration, Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition, June 2008</ref><ref name=efsa>{{cite journal |url=http://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/efsajournal/pub/1489 |doi=10.2903/j.efsa.2010.1489 |title=Scientific Opinion on the substantiation of health claims related to various food(s)/food constituent(s) and protection of cells from premature aging, antioxidant activity, antioxidant content and antioxidant properties, and protection of DNA, proteins and lipids from oxidative damage pursuant to Article 13(1) of Regulation (EC) No 1924/20061 |author=EFSA Panel on Dietetic Products, Nutrition and Allergies |journal=EFSA Journal |year=2010 |volume=8 |issue=2 |pages=1489}}</ref> This guidance for the United States and European Union establishes it is illegal to imply potential health benefits on package labels of products with high ORAC.
==Physiological context== Although research ''in vitro'' indicates [[polyphenol]]s are good [[antioxidant]]s and probably influence the ORAC value, antioxidant effects ''in vivo'' are probably negligible or absent.<ref name=USDAx/><ref name="Williams RJ, Spencer JP, Rice-Evans C 2004 838–49">{{cite journal | vauthors = Williams RJ, Spencer JP, Rice-Evans C | title = Flavonoids: antioxidants or signalling molecules? | journal = Free Radic. Biol. Med. | volume = 36 | issue = 7 | pages = 838–49 | date = April 2004 | pmid = 15019969 | doi = 10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2004.01.001 }}</ref> By ''non''-antioxidant mechanisms still undefined, [[flavonoid]]s and other polyphenols may reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease and cancer.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Arts IC, Hollman PC | title = Polyphenols and disease risk in epidemiologic studies | journal = Am. J. Clin. Nutr. | volume = 81 | issue = 1 Suppl | pages = 317S–325S | year = 2005 | pmid = 15640497 | url = http://www.ajcn.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=15640497 }}</ref>
As interpreted by the [[Linus Pauling Institute]], EFSA and the USDA, dietary polyphenols have little or no direct antioxidant food value following digestion.<ref name=USDAx/><ref name=efsa/><ref name="Williams RJ, Spencer JP, Rice-Evans C 2004 838–49"/><ref name = Lotito>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lotito SB, Frei B | title = Consumption of flavonoid-rich foods and increased plasma antioxidant capacity in humans: cause, consequence, or epiphenomenon? | journal = Free Radic. Biol. Med. | volume = 41 | issue = 12 | pages = 1727–46 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17157175 | doi = 10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2006.04.033 }}</ref> Not like controlled test tube conditions, the fate of polyphenols ''in vivo'' shows they are poorly conserved (less than 5%), with most of what is absorbed existing as chemically modified metabolites destined for rapid excretion.<ref name="LPI">"[http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2007-03/osu-sfn030507.php Studies force new view on biology of flavonoids]", by David Stauth, ''EurekAlert!''. Adapted from a news release issued by Oregon State University</ref>
The increase in antioxidant capacity of blood seen after the consumption of polyphenol-rich (ORAC-rich) foods is not caused directly by the polyphenols, but most likely results from increased [[uric acid]] levels derived from metabolism of flavonoids.<ref name = Lotito/><ref name="LPI"/> According to Frei, "we can now follow the activity of flavonoids in the body, and one thing that is clear is that the body sees them as foreign compounds and is trying to get rid of them."<ref name="LPI"/>
==Food sources== Values are expressed as the sum of the [[lipid]] soluble (e.g. [[carotenoid]]) and [[water-soluble]] (e.g. [[polyphenol|phenolic]]) antioxidant fractions (i.e., “total ORAC”) reported as in micromoles [[trolox]] equivalents (TE) per 100 gram sample, and are compared to assessments of total polyphenol content in the samples.
These values are considered biologically irrelevant by the EFSA and USDA.<ref name=USDAx/><ref name=efsa/>
{| class="wikitable sortable" |+Food ORAC scores - USDA |- ! Food !! Serving size !! ORAC, Trolox equiv., μmol per 100 g |- | [[Prune]] || 1 cup || 14,582 |- | Small Red Bean || ½ cup dried beans || 13,727 |- | Wild [[blueberry]] || 1 cup || 13,427 |- | Red [[kidney bean]] || ½ cup dried beans || 13,259 |- | [[Pinto bean]] || ½ cup || 11,864 |- | [[Cranberry]] || 1 cup raw (whole berries) || 9,584 |- | [[Blueberry]] || 1 cup raw (cultivated berries) || 9,019 |- | [[Artichoke heart]]s || 1 cup, cooked || 7,904 |- | Raw unprocessed [[Cocoa bean]]|| 1 oz || 7.840 |- | [[Blackberry]] || 1 cup raw (cultivated berries) || 7,701 |- | [[Raspberry]] || 1 cup || 6,058 |- | [[Strawberry]] || 1 cup || 5,938 |- | [[Red Delicious]] [[apple]] || 1 apple || 5,900 |- | [[Granny Smith]] apple || 1 apple || 5,381 |- | [[Pecan]] || 1 [[ounce|oz]] || 5,095 |- | [[Prunus avium|Sweet cherry]] || 1 cup || 4,873 |- | Black [[plum]] || 1 plum || 4,844 |- | [[Russet Burbank potato|Russet potato]] || 1, cooked || 4,649 |- | [[Chokeberry]] || 1 oz || 4,497 |- | [[Black turtle bean|Black bean]] || ½ cup dried beans || 4,181 |- | Plum || 1 plum || 4,118 |- | [[Gala (apple)|Gala apple]] || 1 apple || 3,903 |- | [[Pomegranate]] || 100 grams || 2,860 |- |}
With nearly all vegetables, conventional boiling can reduce the ORAC value by up to 90%, while steaming retains more of the antioxidants.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Ninfali P, Mea G, Giorgini S, Rocchi M, Bacchiocca M | title = Antioxidant capacity of vegetables, spices and dressings relevant to nutrition | journal = Br. J. Nutr. | volume = 93 | issue = 2 | pages = 257–66 | year = 2005 | pmid = 15788119 | doi = 10.1079/BJN20041327 }}</ref>
==Comparisons of ORAC values==
The United States Department of Agriculture, previously a publisher of ORAC data, withdrew its web publication of ORAC values for common American foods in 2012 due to absence of scientific evidence that ORAC has any biological significance.<ref name=USDAx/>
When comparing ORAC data, care must be taken to ensure the units and food being compared are similar. Some evaluations will compare ORAC units per gram of dry weight of the intact food or its milled powder, others will evaluate ORAC units in fresh or frozen wet weight, and still others will look at ORAC units per serving. Under each evaluation, different foods can appear to have higher ORAC values. For example, although a raisin has no more antioxidant potential than the grape from which it was dried, raisins will appear to have a higher ORAC value per gram of wet weight than grapes due to their reduced water content. Likewise, the large water content in watermelon can make it appear as though this fruit is low in ORAC. Similarly, the typical quantity of food used should be considered; herbs and spices may be high in ORAC, but are applied in much smaller quantities compared to intact whole foods.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Tapsell LC, Hemphill I, Cobiac L, Patch CS, Sullivan DR, Fenech M, Roodenrys S, Keogh JB, Clifton PM, Williams PG, Fazio VA, Inge KE | title = Health benefits of herbs and spices: the past, the present, the future | journal = Med. J. Aust. | volume = 185 | issue = 4 Suppl | pages = S4–24 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17022438 }}</ref>
Numerous health food and beverage companies and marketers have erroneously capitalized on the ORAC rating by promoting products claimed to be "high in ORAC". As most of these ORAC values have not been independently validated or subjected to [[peer review]] for publication in scientific literature, they remain unconfirmed, are not scientifically credible, and may mislead consumers.

November 2009, 01:50:00|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Rokot]]/[[Briz-KM]] | launch_site = [[Plesetsk Cosmodrome|Plesetsk]] [[Plesetsk Cosmodrome Site 133|133/3]] | launch_contractor = | 2009-059B NORAD 36037|publisher=N2YO|date=24 January 2015|accessdate=25 January 2015}} | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Sun-synchronous orbit|Sun-synchronous]] | insignia_caption = ESA solar system insignia for the ''PROBA-2'' mission | insignia_alt = ''PROBA-2'' mission logo | insignia_size = 180x180px }} '''PROBA-2''' is the second satellite in the [[European Space Agency]]'s series of [[PROBA]] low-cost [[satellite]]s that are being used to validate new spacecraft technologies while also carrying scientific instruments.{{cite web |url=http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Technology/Proba_Missions/About_Proba-2 |title=About PROBA-2 |date=2012-12-02 |publisher=[[ESA]] |accessdate = 2013-04-15}} PROBA-2 is a small satellite (130 kg) developed under an ESA General Support Technology Program (GSTP) contract by a Belgian consortium led by Verhaert (now [[QinetiQ|QinetiQ Space]]) of Kruibeke, Belgium. The nominal mission duration was two years. The mission's most recent extension runs to {{Date|2016-12-31}}.{{cite web |url=http://sci.esa.int/director-desk/54999-working-life-extensions-for-esas-science-missions/ |title=Working life extensions for ESA’s science missions |date=28 November 2014 |website=ESA Science & Technology |publisher=[[European Space Agency|ESA]] |access-date=9 May 2015}} ==Mission summary== It was launched on {{Date|2009-11-2}}, with the [[Rockot]] launch system together with [[ESA]]'s [[Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity satellite|SMOS]] mission.{{cite web |url=http://news.eoportal.org/didyouknow/080923_did1.html |title=Successful launch qualification test for PROBA-2 |date=2008-09-16 |publisher=[[ESA]] |accessdate=2013-04-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725074327/http://news.eoportal.org/didyouknow/080923_did1.html |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }} The platform was launched in a [[Sun-synchronous orbit|sun-synchronous]] [[low Earth orbit]] (altitude of 725 km). PROBA-2 contains five scientific instruments. Two of them are designated to observe the [[Sun]]: "The Sun Watcher using APS and Image Processing" ([[SWAP (instrument)|SWAP]], an EUV imager) and the "Large Yield Radiometer" ([[LYRA]]), a radiometer made of diamond photodiodes. The Principal investigator teams of both instruments are hosted at the [[Royal Observatory of Belgium]]. This institute will also host the [http://proba2.oma.be PROBA-2 Science Center] from which the [[SWAP (instrument)|SWAP]] and [[LYRA]] instruments will be operated and their data distributed. There are three other instruments to measure basic space plasma properties: the [[Dual segmented Langmuir probe]] (DSLP) (developed by the [[Astronomical Institute of Czech Academy of Sciences|Astronomical Institute]] and Institute of Atmospheric Physics, Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic), the Thermal Plasma Measurement Unit (TPMU), and the Science Grade Vector Magnetometer (SGVM) developed by the [[Technical University of Denmark]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== *[[List of European Space Agency programs and missions]] *[[PROBA-1]] *[[PROBA-V]] *[[PROBA-3]] ==External links== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} *[http://Proba2.oma.be PROBA-2 Science Center] {{European Space Agency}} {{Sun spacecraft}} {{Satellite and spacecraft instruments}} {{Orbital launches in 2009}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2009]] [[Category:European Space Agency satellites]] [[Category:Environmental science]] [[Category:Space Situational Awareness Programme]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched by Rokot rockets]] [[Category:Solar space observatories]] [[Category:Technology demonstrations]] {{ESA-stub}} {{Europe-spacecraft-stub}}
